ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The biggest thing I'll take away from this course is a significant improvement in my writing process. Professor Caplan helped me hone my craft through consistent, thoughtful feedback and I am a significantly better writer than at the beginning of 120. The readings were also interesting, teaching me about a wider range of topics than most other writing classes.

This course teaches you the joy of writing. There is a precision involved with English 120 (especially taken with Lincoln Caplan). He will scrutinize every word choice. Linc values, and will teach you to value both concision and clarity.
Ability to read between the lines and just a general ability to understand non-fiction texts
I learned a lot about how to write effective and engaging personal essays.
I really developed my writing and reading analysis skills. I think this class is super helpful for developing writers.

In this class, I developed a true writing process. It's not perfect, but Professor Caplan was instrumental in improving not just my writing itself, but how I produce it. He taught me the value of reading closely and, most importantly, doing a considerable amount of thinking before beginning to write.

A lot was learned in this class, but chief among all was self-sufficiency. The writing process naturally led to lots of self-discovery due to the topics of each essay, and as a result of this, I believe one of the most valuable takeaways from this class is a near-complete understanding of one's own writing process.
time management, how to craft a powerful essay
This course was super helpful in developing my writing skills outside of an academic context. I highly recommend it to anyone looking to learn how to write creative nonfiction.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The pitch, draft, revise sequence worked very well for me; however, on days on or before essays were due, people often didn't come to class. This may be because readings were due on the same day; perhaps use a couple of these days to close read for craft instead of requiring long readings on top of a heavy week of writing?

Strength: Lincoln's feedback is deep, thoughtful, and critical. The workshops in the class were great. You get inspired by your classmates' writings. You also get a chance to hear other views on your essay. Most of the reading with exemplary in both their substance and prose.

Weakness: This is a difficult course. There will be times when you disagree (if only at first) with Linc's feedback. Don't be afraid to ask Linc to clarify.

Strength: engaging readings
Weakness: discussions went flat sometimes, could have less readings as most of the time you wouldn't get through all of them.

I really liked the assigned readings, and thought they were almost all very valuable reads. Each essay implemented tools that we could learn from and apply to our own writing. I also liked the actual essay prompts. 

I dont think the actual structure of the class had any weaknesses.

Strengths  super collaborative. very engaging. extremely important. 

Weaknesses  If you were sick, you missed out on participating in the class because its all discussion based.
I don't think there are many weaknesses to this course

Strength: teaching, feedback
Weakness: N/a

I enjoyed the 5 essay structure, but I feel that I only had enough time to recognize my weaknesses in writing, and did not have enough time to improve my writing skills as much as I hoped. I loved incorporating reading into my workload and found that reading the essays did not feel like work.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. You get out what you put in. There are gutty writing classes; this isn't one of them. But it was well worth it for me.
I would absolutely recommend this course. Looking back on my first draft of our first essay, I can't believe how much my prose has changed. You will learn a lot in discussions.
Yes

If you enjoy personal writing, I recommend this class. Its high volume in that its five essays, draft and revision each, so beware. That being said, it will help you refine your writing process, making the volume of writing more manageable in this class and others.
This course has completely changed how I write. Every Yale student should take it at some point in there time here.
Absolutely. I loved this course and feel like I learned a lot.

Yes, I think it was refreshing to learn and explore a new way of writing, and this course definitely left an impact on me in terms of what I want to study, and do, and how I think of myself as a writer. Whether or not you consider writing a strength of yours, I think this is an excellent course to spend your time on.

Absolutely. For anyone who needs to write in any style other than technical manuals, this course curriculum is instrumental. Additionally, Professor Caplan couldn't have done a better job of presenting the information and providing valuable feedback.

I would recommend it so much, I nearly think it should be mandatory. I love personal writing, and I think this is the perfect course for anyone who either needs an interesting writing credit or wants to devote school time to learning and sharing about themselves.
Yes; great way to improve writing skills, interesting readings

Yes, I would absolutely recommend English 120. No matter your major, the skills you learn are useful in all writing contexts. You get to read meaningful stories, but also learn how writing mechanics make the story even more masterful.
